question.text: What is the correct fate of ammonium ions in plants?

options.text: It undergoes transamination with alpha ketoglutaric acid to form glumate acid which further undergoes reductive amination to form other amino acids
It undergoes reductive amination with alpha ketoglutaric acid to glumatine which further undergoes transamination to form other amino acids
It undergoes transamination with alpha ketoglutaric acid to glumatine which further undergoes reductive amination to form other amino acids
It undergoes reductive amination with alpha ketoglutaric acid to glumate which further undergoes transamination to form other amino acids

solution.text:
At physiological pH, the ammonia is protonated to form (ammonium) ion.

(i) Reductive amination : In these processes, ammonium ion reacts with α-ketoglutaric acid and forms glutamic acid. (ii) Transamination : It involves the transfer of amino group from one amino acid to the keto group of a keto acid. Glutamic acid is the main amino acid from which the transfer of NH2, the amino group takes place and other amino acids are formed through transamination. The enzyme transaminase catalyses all such reactions.
